EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 5.5.1 dated March 26, 2010.
Small Business/Self-Employed Collection employees
Table of Contents
Decedent and Estate Tax Accounts
Program Goals: Provide policy and procedural guidance to IRS Collection employees processing work related to collection of decedent accounts.
Collection and Advisory managers are responsible for ensuring that collection actions taken by employees are in accordance with policy and procedures.
The ENTITY Case Management System can also generate certain, unique reports to assist in managing assigned inventory.
Decedent Estates and Estate (
) Publication
, Survivors, Executors and Administrators (

) Working accounts on deceased taxpayers is one of the more complex and challenging tasks expected from Collection employees. Many procedures for Estate Tax decedent cases are different from those for estate taxes because the nature the liabilities differ and different liens are in effect. (
) Decedent accounts involve tax liabilities that accrued before the death of the taxpayer and remain unpaid. Typically the unpaid taxes result from assess- ments for income tax (Form
), trust fund recovery penalty, or business taxes due from a sole proprietorship or partnership. (
) Assessments are reﬂected under the taxpayer’s SSN or in the case of business taxes the EIN used by that business. The IRC
and IRC
liens are applicable to this type of account. (
) Decedent accounts, liens and collection are addressed in: • IRM
, Decedent and Estate Tax Accounts • IRM
, Probate Proceedings • IRM
, Working Decedent Cases • IRM
, Proof of Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases • IRM
, Legal Reference Guide, Insolvency and Decedent Additional information may also be found in Publication
, Survivors, Executors, and Administrators. (
) Estate taxes are levied on assets comprising the gross estate which are required to be reported on Form
The gross estate includes all property which the decedent had an interest at the time of death. (
) Estate tax accounts are identiﬁed on IDRS under the decedent’s SSN with a “V” indicator (
V). The MFT will always be
and the tax period
The IRC

lien is a special lien for estate and gift tax that arises date of death and attaches to all assets in the gross estate. There are also several special liens applicable to speciﬁc Internal Revenue Code sections relating to estate tax. (
) Estate tax accounts, liens and collection are addressed in: • IRM
, Processing Estate and Gift Tax Extensions • IRM
, Collection on Accounts with Special Estate Tax Elections • IRM
, Collecting Estate and Gift Tax Accounts • IRM
, Advisory Responsibilities for Processing Estate Tax Liens • IRM
, Administrative and Judicial Actions for Estate Taxes (
) An estate is a taxable entity separate from the decedent that comes into on the death of the individual. It exists until the ﬁnal distribution of its assets the heirs and other beneﬁciaries. (
) The income earned by assets of the estate must be reported on Form
, U.S. Income Tax Return for Estates and Trusts, if there is $
or more of income during a tax year. The estate’s income, like an individual’s income, must be reported annually on either a calendar or ﬁscal year basis. Schedule K-
is ﬁled with the return and provided to beneﬁciaries that receive income from the estate. Additional information may be found in Publication
, Survivors, Executors, and Administrators. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Y
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate Taxes
Publication 559, Survivors, Executors and Administrators
The income earned by assets of the estate must be reported on Form
, U.S. Income Tax Return for Estates and Trusts, if there is $
or more of income during a tax year. The estate’s income, like an individual’s income, must be reported annually on either a calendar or ﬁscal year basis. Schedule K-
is ﬁled with the return and provided to beneﬁciaries that receive income from the estate. Additional information may be found in Publication
, Survivors, Executors, and Administrators.

An additional resource is IRM 5.17.13, Legal Reference Guide, Insolvency and Decedents Estates, employees may confer with local Counsel and/or Advisory when working decedent taxpayer accounts. Modiﬁcation of procedures may be necessary to conform to the speciﬁc legal requirements for each state.

include: Testate - person who died testate had a will. A will typically appoints a ﬁduciary to handle affairs after the taxpayer’s death and speciﬁes ben- eﬁciaries to receive the assets. Intestate - person who died intestate did not have a will. State law de- termines how the assets will be distributed. Dependent, Supervised or Formal Probate - the term differs by state, but all indicate that assets of the deceased are under control of the probate court. Enforcement actions are prohibited, and the CSED is suspended under IRC section

(b). Independent, Unsupervised or Informal Probate - the term differs by state but all indicate that assets of the deceased may not be deemed to be under the control of the probate court. The CSED is not suspended and collection actions can be pursued. See “Note” in IRM

) concerning possible extension of the CSED when a proof of claim is ﬁled during a state probate proceeding to collect the unpaid tax liability. Fiduciary - the person who is the point of contact on a decedent case, acting as power of attorney. A ﬁduciary’s primary function is to see that all debts of the decedent are paid and remaining assets are distributed. Fiduciaries are commonly called administrators, executors, or personal representatives. Beneﬁciary, Devisee or Heir - person or recipient who receives real or personal property as stated in the will or in accordance with state probate law.
Below is a list of common probate documents that should be reviewed for in- formation on the decedent, ﬁduciary and distribution of assets:
a. Death certiﬁcate
provides date of death, where taxpayer died, cause of death and other data pertaining to the deceased. b. Will
a document containing instructions and wishes as to how property and assets are to be distributed after death. c. Letters testamentary
a document issued by the probate court that an executor the power to take control of and distribute a deceased person’s property. d. Inventory and appraisement
a listing and valuation of properties owned by the decedent. e. Annual accounting
a document that lists assets and liabilities, it the condition of the estate as time progresses.

Decedent Estates and Estate f. Status reports - show claims and distributions. Claims ﬁled by creditors can be a source of information about insolvency or encumbrances property. g. Bond - a probate bond is a bond issued on the performance of an istrator or executor. Its purpose is to protect heirs and creditors from being harmed by the negligence or malfeasance of the administrator executor. Depending on circumstances, a bond may be levied if the executor pays lower priority creditors ahead of federal taxes due. (
) Refer to IRM
, Probate Proceedings, to guide you through evaluating protecting the Government’s interest during probate proceedings. (
) The manner in which title passes determines whether an asset is a probate asset or a non-probate asset. (
) Title to probate property passes to the decedent’s estate and a probate pro- ceeding may be necessary to transfer the property to heirs. (

) Probate property is property the deceased owned at the time of his or her death or that is payable to the estate. For example, if a house, car, RV, and bank account are all in the name of the deceased at the time of death, items of property will have to be included in the probate estate and go the probate procedure before they can be legally transferred to the ries. If the estate of the deceased is named as the beneﬁciary of an policy, the proceeds of the policy will be included in the probate estate. and beneﬁts due to the deceased and money collected from debts owed to deceased are part of the probate estate as well. (

) Non-probate property is primarily those assets of the decedent that were ferred prior to death or were held in a way that ownership transferred automatically upon death. Non probate assets do not come under control of the court. They may be distributed without court approval. (

) Some examples of non-probate property include: • Transfers taking effect at death (payable on death accounts such as checking or savings accounts). • IRA’s and retirement accounts that are payable to a designated or survivor rather than the decedent’s estate. • Property held jointly with rights of survivorship by decedent and any other person (such as a spouse). • Life insurance proceeds paid to a designated beneﬁciary other than decedent’s estate. • Property held in a revocable or living trust, with a designated beneﬁ- ciary. (

) State law normally dictates which courts administer estates or probate wills. is generally in the jurisdiction of the court in the place of residence when the on taxpayer died, however, more then one probate proceeding may be opened the taxpayer owned property in more than one state.

a probate bond is a bond issued on the performance of an admin

istrator or executor. Its purpose is to protect heirs and creditors from being harmed by the negligence or malfeasance of the administrator or executor. Depending on circumstances, a bond may be levied if the executor pays lower priority creditors ahead of federal taxes due.
Refer to IRM 5.5.2, Probate Proceedings, to guide you through evaluating protecting the Government’s interest during probate proceedings.
5.5.1.5 (03-26-2010) Probate and Non-Probate Property

Probate property is property the deceased owned at the time of his or her death or that is payable to the estate. For example, if a house, car, RV, and bank account are all in the name of the deceased at the time of death, those items of property will have to be included in the probate estate and go through the probate procedure before they can be legally transferred to the beneﬁcia- ries. If the estate of the deceased is named as the beneﬁciary of an insurance policy, the proceeds of the policy will be included in the probate estate. Salary and beneﬁts due to the deceased and money collected from debts owed to
Transfers taking effect at death (payable on death accounts such as checking or savings accounts).
IRA’s and retirement accounts that are payable to a designated or survivor rather than the decedent’s estate.
Property held jointly with rights of survivorship by decedent and any other person (such as a spouse).
Life insurance proceeds paid to a designated beneﬁciary other than decedent’s estate.
Property held in a revocable or living trust, with a designated beneﬁ
ciary.

) State law normally dictates which courts administer estates or probate wills. It is generally in the jurisdiction of the court in the place of residence when the taxpayer died, however, more then one probate proceeding may be opened if the taxpayer owned property in more than one state. (

) Speciﬁc details of state probate proceedings vary widely and must be followed explicitly. Local law guides should be reviewed, and local Counsel should be consulted on provisions of speciﬁc state probate codes and their potential impact on collection. See additional guidance in IRM
, Probate Proceed-

State law normally dictates which courts administer estates or probate wills. It is generally in the jurisdiction of the court in the place of residence when the taxpayer died, however, more then one probate proceeding may be opened if the taxpayer owned property in more than one state.

ings. Refer to your local law guide for speciﬁc state law information at ccintranet.prod.irscounsel.treas.gov/Or

uides.aspx. (

) The following are actions commonly taken in probate proceedings. They cannot be generalized to apply in all circumstances. The existence of a will the factor that most often inﬂuences a proceeding. The primary effect of a is that it speciﬁcally names the party who will administer the estate and out how the estate property will be distributed after administration is (

) A person who died testate had a will, which typically appoints a ﬁduciary to handle affairs after the taxpayer’s death. When there is a will ﬁled with the court by the executor, after its authenticity is declared, the executor is rized to: a. gather the assets, b. pay the debts of the deceased, and c. make distribution to the beneﬁciaries as speciﬁed by the will. (

) A person who died intestate did not have a will. When there is no will, a petition is ﬁled requesting the appointment of an administrator. The court appoints an administrator and issues letters testamentary authorizing the ministrator to: a. gather the assets, b. pay the debts of the deceased, and c. make distribution to the heirs as dictated by state law or ordered by court. (

) The revenue officer must determine from the probate records if the is dependent, supervised or formal. The term differs by state, but all indicate that assets of the deceased are under the control of the probate court. En- forcement actions are prohibited, but a NFTL may be recorded because probate proceedings are not subject to an automatic stay as are bankruptcy proceedings. (
) If the proceeding is independent, unsupervised or informal, then assets of deceased may not be deemed to be under control of the probate court. tion action may be pursued. (
) See “Note” in IRM
) concerning possible extension of the CSED when a proof of claim is ﬁled during a state probate proceeding to collect unpaid tax liability. (

) Some states have statutes that allow for the distribution of assets without formal probate proceedings. For example, property may be transferred by affidavit and problems or questions may be handled by an administrative hearing. This is particularly true when most of the property is held in joint tenancy with right of survivorship or when there is only one heir. (

) The ﬁduciary is the person who is the point of contact on a decedent case, acting as the power of attorney. In probate documents you may see the ﬁduciary referred to as administrator, executor or personal representative. (
) A ﬁduciary may be identiﬁed in the will, by the probate court in letters testa- mentary, or by Form
, Notice Concerning Fiduciary Relationship. A third Internal Revenue Manual
ings. Refer to your local law guide for speciﬁc state law information at https://

A ﬁduciary may be identiﬁed in the will, by the probate court in letters testa- mentary, or by Form 56, Notice Concerning Fiduciary Relationship. A third
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
Decedent Estates and Estate party authorization (Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Repre- sentative, Form
, Tax Information Authorization) expires with the death the taxpayer. Do not assume the surviving spouse is the executor for the deceased spouse. (
) An individual representing a deceased taxpayer should sign the Form

to have the following effect: “ upon notice to the Secretary that any person is acting for another person in a ﬁduciary capacity, such ﬁduciary shall assume the powers, rights, duties, and privileges of such other person in respect of tax imposed by this title, until notice is given that the ﬁduciary capacity has minated. ” IRC§
) Essentially, after signing the Form
, the ﬁduciary steps into the shoes of taxpayer and has all the same power, rights and duties as the taxpayer. The ﬁduciary can sign the decedent’s last tax return (see Treas. Reg. §
)) or Form
, Consent to Extend Time to Assess the Tax. Additional information may be found in IRM
, Decedents. (
) Processing instructions for Form
are in IRM
, Form
, Notice Concerning Fiduciary Relationship. (

) The ﬁduciary (executor or administrator) must post a bond to be authorized act for the estate unless the will or probate court authorizes the ﬁduciary to without one. The bond exists to protect all whose interests may be by the action or inaction of the ﬁduciary. The bond is in effect an insurance policy with a designated policy limit for the payment of claims. (

) After gathering assets and determining debts due by the estate, the a. prepares an inventory of estate assets, b. approves or disapproves creditor claims, (A creditor may argue its before the probate court. If an adverse decision is rendered there, the creditor may appeal to a higher court) and c. distributes to the beneﬁciaries any assets that remain after payment of creditors and expenses. (
) The ﬁduciary must ﬁle the decedent’s ﬁnal income tax return for the year of death and any returns not ﬁled for preceding years. The decedent’s income to date of death is includible on a Form
) The date of death determines the end of the decedent’s tax year and the beginning of the estate’s tax year. After the taxpayer’s death the ﬁduciary is required to ﬁle Form
, U.S. Income Tax Return for Estates and Trusts, report gross income of $
or more. If you encounter substitute for return (SFR) assessments for tax periods after death, request the ﬁduciary to properly report the income on a Form
Publication
, Survivors, Executors, and Administrators, provides information about how to complete and ﬁle federal income tax returns and points out responsibility to pay any taxes due. (
) If the decedent owned a business, the ﬁduciary is required to secure a new employer identiﬁcation number (EIN) if the estate operates the business the owner’s death. Publication
, Understanding Your EIN, provides mation about this requirement.

party authorization (Form 2848, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Repre- sentative, Form 8821, Tax Information Authorization) expires with the death of the taxpayer. Do not assume the surviving spouse is the executor for the deceased spouse.

) The ﬁduciary has an obligation to ﬁle and sign outstanding returns for the estate. Requests for delinquent tax returns should be addressed with the ﬁduciary for the estate. (

) If the ﬁduciary does not comply with deadlines to ﬁle tax returns, issue a summons to secure tax information not available through internal resources such as IDRS or IRP. Follow unﬁled return procedures in IRM

, No Return Secured, for additional information on referrals of substitute returns. This information may be necessary for Advisory to submit a proof of claim an estimate of taxes due on unﬁled returns. (

) Local Counsel can help with drafting document requests for the summons. the ﬁduciary ignores the summons, Counsel can seek enforcement in the federal courts instead of waiting for a state court to act. (
) When a business is involved, it may be necessary to prepare returns under IRC
(b) if they are not ﬁled voluntarily. See IRM
, IRC Authority, for IRC
(b) procedures. (

) The determination to pursue or not pursue a return will depend upon the of each case. Factors to be considered include whether assets are satisfy any part of a tax liability and possibility of a transferee or trust fund penalty assessment. (

AC

is an identity theft indicator used to lock the account deceased taxpayers. It prevents a deceased taxpayer’s TIN (SSN or ITIN) being used as the primary, secondary or dependent TIN on a current or quent year federal income tax return. For more information on the code see IRM
, Locking Decedent Accounts - TC
AC
) For questions on disclosure, who may receive copies of tax returns or tax return information see IRM
, Deceased Individuals. (

) Independent, unsupervised or informal probate proceedings indicate that assets of the deceased may not be deemed to be under control of the court. The CSED is not suspended and collection action may be pursued. Note: A proof of claim ﬁled on behalf of the Service during a state probate pro- ceeding may be considered commencement of a “ court action brought against the taxpayer to collect tax” and toll the statute of limitations in
(a) extending the period of time to collect. See United States v.

The TC 971 AC 524 is an identity theft indicator used to lock the account of deceased taxpayers. It prevents a deceased taxpayer’s TIN (SSN or ITIN) being used as the primary, secondary or dependent TIN on a current or subse- quent year federal income tax return. For more information on the transaction code see IRM 25.23.2.8.4, Locking Decedent Accounts - TC 971 AC 524.

If a TC 608 posts prematurely in a case, actions must be taken to reestablish the assessed balance and to revoke the premature release of any NFTL’s. If the TC 608/TC 583’s are pending on TXMOD, take the following actions:

• check ALS to see if the issuance of physical certiﬁcate(s) of release is pending. If so, contact the Centralized Lien Operation (CLO ) unit to if mailing of the certiﬁcate(s) can be stopped. • Request input of TC
cc
, using a transaction code input date is at least one day (

) prior to the CSED. • If the NFTL certiﬁcate(s) of release have already been issued, make a determination as to possible harm to the Government’s priority and related litigation (it may be effective, depending when the documents were sent, to contact the county recorder and request they pull the releases and not record them). • Advise Area Counsel if a TC
posts on an account that is in litiga- tion.
